    Dependency injection container.

    package Aura.Di

     Methods

    When cloning this Container, *do not* make a copy of the service objects.

    __clone() : void

    Leave the configuration and definitions intact.

    Constructor.

    __construct(Aura\Di\ForgeInterface $forge) 

    Parameters

    $forge

    \Aura\Di\ForgeInterface

    A forge for creating objects using keyword parameter configuration.

    Magic get to provide access to the Config::$params and $setter objects.

    Parameters

    The property to retrieve ('params' or 'setter').

    Gets a service object by key, lazy-loading it as needed.

    isLocked() : bool

    Returns

    bool

    Returns a Lazy containing a general-purpose callable.

    lazy(callable $callable) : \Aura\Di\Lazy

    Use this when you have complex logic or heavy overhead when creating a param that may or may not need to be loaded.

     $di->params['ClassName']['param_name'] = $di->lazy(function () {
     return include 'filename.php';
 });

    Parameters

    $callable

    \Aura\Di\callable

    The callable functionality.

    Returns

    \Aura\Di\LazyA lazy-load object that contains the callable.

    Returns a Lazy that invokes a callable (e.g., to call a method on an object).

    lazyCall(\Aura\Di\callable $callable) : \Aura\Di\Lazy

    Parameters

    $callable

    \Aura\Di\callable

    The callable. Params after this one are treated as params for the call.

    Returns

    \Aura\Di\Lazy

    Returns a Lazy that gets a service.

    lazyGet(string $key) : \Aura\Di\Lazy

    This allows you to replace the following idiom ...

     $di->params['ClassName']['param_name'] = $di->lazy(function() use ($di)) {
     return $di->get('service');
 }

    ... with the following:

     $di->params['ClassName']['param_name'] = $di->lazyGet('service');

    Parameters

    $key

    string

    The service name; it does not need to exist yet.

    Returns

    \Aura\Di\LazyA lazy-load object that gets the named service.

    Returns a lazy that includes a file.

    lazyInclude(string $file) : \Aura\Di\Lazy

    This replaces the idiom ...

    $di->params['ClassName']['foo'] = $di->lazy(function () {
    return include "/path/to/file.php";
};

    ... with:

    $di->params['ClassName']['foo'] = $di->lazyRequire("/path/to/file.php");

    Parameters

    $file

    string

    The file to include.

    Returns

    \Aura\Di\Lazy

    Returns a Lazy that creates a new instance.

    lazyNew(string $class, array $params, array $setters) : \Aura\Di\Lazy

    This allows you to replace the following idiom:

     $di->params['ClassName']['param_name'] = $di->lazy(function () use ($di)) {
     return $di->newInstance('OtherClass', [...]);
 });

    ... with the following:

     $di->params['ClassName']['param_name'] = $di->lazyNew('OtherClass', [...]);

    Parameters

    $class

    string

    The type of class of instantiate.

    $params

    array

    Override parameters for the instance.

    $setters

    array

    Override setters for the instance

    Returns

    \Aura\Di\LazyA lazy-load object that creates the new instance.

    Returns a lazy that requires a file.

    lazyRequire(string $file) : \Aura\Di\Lazy

    This replaces the idiom ...

    $di->params['ClassName']['foo'] = $di->lazy(function () {
    return require "/path/to/file.php";
};

    ... with:

    $di->params['ClassName']['foo'] = $di->lazyRequire("/path/to/file.php");

    Parameters

    $file

    string

    The file to require.

    Returns

    \Aura\Di\Lazy

    Lock the Container so that configuration cannot be accessed externally, and no new service definitions can be added.

    lock() : void

    Returns a Factory that creates an object over and over again (as vs creating it one time like the lazyNew() or newInstance() methods).

    newFactory(string $class, array $params, array $setters) : \Aura\Di\Factory

    Parameters

    $class

    string

    THe factory will create an instance of this class.

    $params

    array

    Override parameters for the instance.

    $setters

    array

    Override setters for the instance.

    Returns

    \Aura\Di\Factory

    Returns a new instance of the specified class, optionally with additional override parameters.

    newInstance(string $class, array $params, array $setters) : object

    Parameters

    $class

    string

    The type of class of instantiate.

    $params

    array

    Override parameters for the instance.

    $setters

    array

    Override setters for the instance.

    Returns

    objectAn instance of the requested class.

    Sets a service definition by name.

    set(string $key, object $val) : \Aura\Di\$this

    If you set a service as a Closure, it is automatically treated as a Lazy. (Note that is has to be a Closure, not just any callable, to be treated as a Lazy; this is because the actual service object itself might be callable via an __invoke() method.)

    Parameters

    $key

    string

    The service key.

    $val

    object

    The service object; if a Closure, is treated as a Lazy.

    Exceptions

    \Aura\Di\Exception\ContainerLocked when the Container is locked.
    \Aura\Di\Exception\Service

    Returns

    \Aura\Di\$this

    Retains named service definitions.

    $defs : array

     

    A Forge object to create classes through reflection.

    $forge : array

     

    Is the Container locked? (When locked, you cannot access configuration properties from outside the object, and cannot set services.)

    $locked : bool

    see \Aura\Di\__get()
    see \Aura\Di\set()
     

    A convenient reference to the Config::$params object, which itself is contained by the Forge object.

    $params : \ArrayObject

     

    Retains the actual service objects.

    $services : array

     

    A convenient reference to the Config::$setter object, which itself is contained by the Forge object.
